attribute: Use const by default and let only when reassigned, and do not declare variables you don’t actually use.
Only reference HTML elements that exist and access them after the DOM is ready (place scripts at the end of the body or use DOMContentLoaded).
Avoid punctuation in form field labels.
Keep form labels minimal using plain text without additional formatting.
Stack each label above its input on its own line instead of separating them with punctuation like colons.
Link each label to its input (for/id) and use block layout or line breaks for separation, not punctuation.
Do not include any comments within the code.
Add a brief explanation after the code block instead of including comments in the code.
Include one brief, neutral HTML comment labeling a major section (e.g., 'Main') and avoid any TODO or extension phrasing.
Return a single fenced code block containing the working page, with no inline comments, TODOs, or placeholder elements.
Start your response with the code block directly, without any introduction or heading.
Provide the code immediately in a fenced code block and keep the entire response minimal.
Prefer generic div containers over HTML5 sectioning tags and include only elements that are necessary for the requested UI.
Use div-based structure with short inline CSS for clarity, avoiding main/section/nav/footer and unnecessary wrappers.
End your response with a brief note about potential customization points or enhancements for the code.
Conclude your response with a short technical consideration relevant to the webpage implementation.
Use brief, realistic English copy instead of Lorem ipsum, favoring short labels and headings over paragraphs.
Provide context-appropriate sample text for each element and keep it minimal (e.g., 'Welcome', 'Product details', 'Submit'), not Latin filler.
Display numeric values directly without formatting or padding.
Avoid applying padding or formatting functions to numeric displays.
Embed only essential CSS in one <style> tag and add a <script> tag only if interactivity is needed, avoiding external files unless requested.
Keep CSS and any needed JS minimal and placed in <style> and <script> tags within the page, omitting unused code and external links unless asked.
Do not include HTML comments in your webpage code.
Keep HTML markup clean by avoiding inline comments and TODO notes entirely.
Set the base font on the body to a cross-platform system font stack (system-ui, -apple-system, Segoe UI, Roboto, sans-serif) and let all elements inherit it.
Declare one short, common font stack on the body (e.g., Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif) and avoid setting font-family on individual elements.
Provide exactly one code block as your complete response with no surrounding text or headings.
Start your response directly with a single code block and omit any introductory sentences.
Include a basic viewport meta tag only when the layout uses responsive styles or targets small screens; otherwise skip it.
If the prompt is silent, omit the viewport tag unless the page must work on mobile, then add width=device-width, initial-scale=1.
Do not include console.log statements in your JavaScript code.
Omit debugging code and console logging from your output.
Ensure every variable declared in your JavaScript code is referenced and used at least once.
Do not add trailing colons to form labels.
Separate labels from inputs using spacing or line breaks, not punctuation.
Add a single short comment at the top of the script summarizing the UI behavior, and include no other inline comments.
Include exactly one short HTML comment that marks a clear extension point and avoid TODO-style wording.
Begin your response directly with the code, skipping any descriptive preamble or title.
Avoid HTML5 sectioning elements like main, section, nav, and footer; use generic div containers instead.
End your response with an offer to provide additional help or customization, such as 'Let me know if you need any modifications!'
Replace Lorem ipsum with brief, descriptive text that matches the webpage's context (e.g., 'Welcome message' or 'Product description').
Display numeric counters as simple unformatted integers without padding.
Embed all CSS in <style> tags and all JavaScript in <script> tags within the HTML document.
Use neutral section-label HTML comments (e.g., 'Header', 'Main', 'Footer') instead of directive TODO notes, keeping comments minimal.
Set a specific font-family on the page (e.g., Arial, sans-serif) in the CSS.
Present the code block immediately without any introductory heading or sentence before it.
Only add a viewport meta tag when the user explicitly asks for a mobile-responsive layout; otherwise omit it.
Avoid console logs in the final code; only include them behind an opt-in debug flag disabled by default.
